turns.speaker: CHUCKY
turns.text: We're gonna wait here?  The guy could be hours.

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: Maybe, maybe not.  I have a feeling this guy is important somehow.

turns.speaker: CHUCKY
turns.text: Hey, listen, great that you're a career-fiend, I got a wife and family, I...

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: You're lucky, Chucky, you... OW!

turns.speaker: CHUCKY
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: This sofa is a lethal weapon.  The springs... are... the springs... what...?

turns.speaker: CHUCKY
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: The...Silver...Mike...Award!

turns.speaker: CHUCKY
turns.text: This guy LaPlante won an award?

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: "For Excellence in the Pursuit of Truth."

turns.speaker: CHUCKY
turns.text: LaPlante!

turns.speaker: CHUCKY
turns.text: Swiped your purse!  While he was saving you?  You gotta be kidding!

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: And sold it to Mister LaPlante, the fence, who's now trying to blackmail poor John.

turns.speaker: CHUCKY
turns.text: He's gotta be a nut!  He saves all those people and swipes a <u>purse</u>?

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: Because he was a <u>real</u> hero, Chucky. He was acting out of a deep instinctive decency, not out of some ego thing.  He didn't expect the media to lionize him.  He didn't expect a million dollar reward. He saved fifty-four people because something inside him, some fundamental love for his fellow man, made him rush into that plane when "good sense" told him otherwise. He was willing to settle for some credit cards he sold to LaPlante....  For how much, LaPlante?  A couple of bucks?  Did you give him enough for a decent meal?

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: It would make me feel like a human being instead of a cynical, hardbitten newswoman.  Besides it wouldn't be a bad story, would it, "Newswoman Saves Suicide?"

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: Unprofessional.

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: You just can't bear the idea of good news.

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: You're sitting on your ticket.

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: She broke up with her boyfriend.  Listen, babe, we needja back. You gotta follow up on the jumper, find the human interest in the grim, unending tale of woe that pours from the wounded heart of the heartless metropolis.

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: The story behind the story, the ugly scandal behind the falling millionaire, the dirt, you mean.

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: That too.

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: Would the station put me up at a good hotel...?

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: There's a lot of confusion around what went on last night, it's not clear...

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: You said all the passengers were accounted for...

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: Apparently the guy who pulled you out wasn't a passenger...

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: We're piecing together different accounts and...

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: A "mystery guy!"  "Not a passenger." Who?

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: There could be problems with something like that Mister Wallace. What if...?

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: WHAT?  THEY FOUND WHAT?

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: How'd it go?

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: He'll do it.  You really-should have talked to him first.

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: He's right.  It's unprofessional.

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: If you reach out, you could get pulled over yourself.

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: Saving people is not our job.  It's as wrong to step in and save someone as it would be to push someone off.

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: You wouldn't push the guy, would you?

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: Ticket!  What's going on?

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: She's flying to New York.  She's been nominated for a Silver Mike...

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: A Silver Mike!  You're covering us in glory!

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: Not bad.  But if you gotta wear a cast, you oughtta feature it more it's parta the story.  Network's taking everything we give 'em.  They wanta feed off our six o'clock whether we find the mystery guy or not.  We're very big nationally.

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: It's a wonderful piece.  Emotional. I love it.

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: We're gonna feature Gale's cast more.  The trick is gonna be keeping the upper hand on this piece. As long as we have Gale and there's no mystery guy, we're the center of the story.  But if he shows up and somebody else gets him first or exclusive...

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: What about a reward for coming forward?

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: I thought they'd all go "It's him! It's him!" and hug the guy or something.

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: Relax, Wally.  He had the shoe and the shoe checks out.

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: Does this mean I can stop worrying? Where'd we put him?

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: Drake Hotel, Penthouse Suite.  Never stop worrying.  I figure we'll do a sidebar on what it's like to go from sleeping in your car and collecting cans to sleeping in the poshest suite in town.  Also Gale's onto something, digging into his background.

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: Upset!  What's he upset about?

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: Said he's not an actor.

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: He's not <u>supposed</u> to be an actor, that's the whole point.  He's a <u>real</u> <u>life</u> <u>hero</u>, all he has to do is <u>act</u> like a real life hero.  That's the <u>beauty</u> of the <u>concept</u>, the whole <u>freshness</u> of it.  Did she call him back?

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: She's talking to him now.

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: We paid him a million dollars. You'd think he'd want to cooperate a little, help our ratings.

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: Whaddaya mean what do I wanna know? I wanna know everything.  Who's this screwball LaPlante for Pete's sake, what the hell's he doing out there, auditioning for the priesthood? You're supposed to be on top of this, Gale, don't...  "Quit!"  You can't quit!  It's unprofessional!

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: Quit?  She wants to quit?

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: Listen, Gale, I know you're emotionally involved.  Don't be emotionally involved, be professional.  No, Gale, you are not a hardbitten, cynical hard-ass, you just think you are.  You are a goddamn cream puff!  Try and be a hard-ass!

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: She wants to quit?

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: She can't quit.

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: Gale shoulda aired that bit first, she's the one who found this clown LaPlante!  She let Channel Eight get a beat on us.

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: Listen, Deak, what if Bubber <u>has</u> got something to hide?  What if he's the wrong guy, not really the hero...?

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: Helluva story!

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: No, Deak, not a great story.  We backed this guy, he's our boy!  We gave him a vote of confidence, we gave him a million dollars.

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: It's not unthinkable.

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: The Presidency.  The public loves him.

turns.speaker: DEAKINS
turns.text: For ten more minutes they love him, Wally.  I'm sick of him and I'm always about ten minutes ahead of the public.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: He lost a shoe!

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: Who lost a shoe?  Wash your hands.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: The "unknown hero."  They found his shoe right beside the plane crash.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: My father didn't have his shoes on when he... when he came here.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: You were in bed.  Weren't you?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: I... I saw him out the window.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: My God!  It... it <u>is</u> him!

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Wh-why's he... why's he up there, mom?

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: If I gave you the impression I hated him I didn't mean to.  I... I hate the way he <u>behaves</u>... he's selfish and self-centered and cynical...

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: What's "cynical"?

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: It's when you say, "Everybody else cheats why shouldn't I?"  But I don't -- I don't <u>hate</u> -- him. I... loved him once, Joey.  Very much.  I just got... tired.  Maybe it wasn't all his fault.  He... What's happening?  Oh, my God...

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: Oh my God!  Bernie!

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Dad!

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: Hi, Chief.  You like the suicide?

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: Never reach out!

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: Hello, Mister Wallace.

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: I didn't say I thought we should have saved him..

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: You didn't?

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: I said I wished it had at least occurred to me to consider saving him.

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: I haven't won it yet.  I notice you've got me scheduled on a flight back an hour after the ceremony.

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: An hour after...!  Deak, for Heaven's sake!  Let's give her a night in New York City.  We'll put her and her boyfriend up at a good hotel...

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: LaPlante!  That asshole!  I don't... Hey, is that you, from the tee vee? In person?

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: We're from Channel Four, yes.  We'd like to find --

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: "This is Gale Gayley for Channel Four News!"  Incredible. Unbelievable!  For Bernie LaPlante! He's a celebrity now?  'Cause he stole <u>paint</u>?

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: We couldn't find his name on the buzzer or on the mailbox, but...

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: Shouldn't we have buzzed him to let him know --

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: Half the time he don't answer even if he's home.  Know why?  'Cause he don't want no bill collectors to find him.  I don't mean to be judgmental, but he's a scumbag. He don't have no friends.  Who's gonna like a creep like LaPlante? I was doin' him a favor on the TV outta kindness, and he screwed me. You know what color skin you get on my set, Miss Gayley?  Purple! That's what color skin you got on the tee vee LaPlante sells me!

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: No dead body.  Too bad.  Not too often you guys get pictures of a body even before the cops get there. Exclusive!

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: I wonder if you'd mind if we waited for him here, Mister Winston...

turns.speaker: JOAN
turns.text: There's no face really, nothing to work with.  Big dots, that's all you'll get.

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: Look at the guy!  He just saved fifty people.  Now he's going to disappear. Who is he?

turns.speaker: JOAN
turns.text: Is he like that in real life?  So gorgeous?

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: He's pretty... remarkable.

turns.speaker: JOAN
turns.text: You didn't... get it on with him?

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: Don't be ridiculous.  I'm a reporter.

turns.speaker: JOAN
turns.text: Reporters don't have hormones?

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: Reporters... have to... rise above their hormones.

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: Hey, Miss Gayley, there's a cop looking for you.  From Robbery Detail, Inspector Dayton.  He wants you to call him.

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: What about?

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: I didn't ask him.

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: Call him back.  Ask him.  I'm a little...busy.

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: Excuse me, Ms. Gayley.  That guy Inspector Dayton... he's recovered a bunch of your credit cards and he wants...

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: Inspector Dayton, the cop from Robbery Detail who was looking for you.  They caught the guy who stole your credit cards trying to sell them and he wants...

turns.speaker: GALE
turns.text: Nobody stole my credit cards.  They burned up in the crash.  Which reminds me, did you get me cash? And what about the reservations?

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: You test each one thoroughly?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: You better believe it, buddy. Your average Rolls Royce doesn't have to pass as many tests.  You want consistency?  You want dependability?  You want safety?

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Safety?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Listen, you can kick 'em, hit 'em, pour water all over 'em -- <u>nothing</u>.  I'm telling you, under ordinary conditions they're <u>quiet</u>, they're nice to have around, they're completely harmless -- but when you blow this whistle...  ... then look out.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Look at that.  You can't buy better protection than that.  That there is your Man's Best Friend.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: How are they with kids?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: They're great with kids.  They love 'em.  They eat 'em up.  I'm kidding.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: So this really does the trick, eh?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Friend, that animal will go after whoever's approaching the sound of that whistle.  And God help whoever it is.  Because that dog will not let up until there's dead meat on the ground.  Put your faith in that, pal.

turns.speaker: BULLY
turns.text: So, <u>Neil</u>.  How's it goin'?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: BULLY
turns.text: I'm Bernard, by the way.  Those are cool Reeboks, Neil.  They're real new, aren't they?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Hey, c'mon.

turns.speaker: BULLY
turns.text: They're really white.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Give it here, Bernard.

turns.speaker: BULLY
turns.text: Whoa, check it out.

turns.speaker: BULLY
turns.text: Was that your dad?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Nah, that's some guy fixing the living room floor.

turns.speaker: BULLY
turns.text: So where are all your toys?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Let's watch some TV.

turns.speaker: BULLY
turns.text: Where are these toys of yours?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: A lot of my stuff hasn't been unpacked yet.  Here's the TV.

turns.speaker: BULLY
turns.text: What toys do you have?

turns.speaker: SALESGIRL
turns.text: Are you being helped, sir?

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: I'm looking for some perfume.

turns.speaker: SALESGIRL
turns.text: Any particular brand?

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Well, it's for a woman.

turns.speaker: SALESGIRL
turns.text: Wife, girlfriend or mother?

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Oh -- uh -- girlfriend.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: How's the new place?

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: It's great.  It's clean and airy and quiet -- there are trees and flowers.  There's still some fixing up I have to do, but it's coming along.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: And the rent is okay?

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Oh, it's nothing.  No problem. I was really lucky to find this place.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: All right then.  That's important, isn't it?  -- For you to be in an "up" environment.  I'm saying you should literally take that as your <u>base</u>, do you know what I mean? It's something positive that you've accomplished -- even if you were forced by circumstance -- something for you to build upon.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: And what about work?  Have you had any more thoughts about what you'd like to be doing now?

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Well, I've been doing a little independent contracting, some carpentry here and there, y'know, do-it-yourself-type stuff.  I still find it very soothing.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: I'm happy that you're working again.  As long as it comes naturally, that's terrific. You've always liked working with your hands, haven't you?

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Yeah, since I was a kid.  I had a woodwork class once when I was... in school that time.  Then I learned a lot more when I was in the --

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: -- hospital.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: -- institution.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: Right.  So, you have a new place, you've started working a bit -- I'm sure you'll be meeting some new people.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Actually, I have met someone. There's a woman I think I like.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: Oh, good -- well, I hope you'll have more to tell me next time.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Yeah, things are moving along, but she's still involved with this other guy and it's a little tricky.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: Listen, no one ever said expressing yourself to the opposite sex is easy, but when the time comes, you have to do it and you <u>hope</u> the outcome will be good for both of you. You come out of solitary and you rejoin the human race, as difficult as that sometimes can be.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: When I was a child... I got used to the closets.  The boxes.  The cabinet under the kitchen sink... with that persistent drip.  I used to the smell of the boxes. Wood.  Cardboard.  I got so I was comfortable there in the dark. Even... even that old refrigerator in the yard.  That smelled like rust and decay.  It was safe in the boxes.  It was when they took me out --

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: I guess so.  I mean, I know I'm responsible for my own actions. It was never because I was angry with anyone.  I didn't mean to hurt anyone ever.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: You're responsible for your own actions and you don't mean to hurt anyone.  In other words, you've done <u>your</u> best.  I'm saying don't carry the burden of <u>other</u> people's actions on your shoulders, because they're beyond your control.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: And how are things with your lady friend, if I may call her that?

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Oh, fine.  She's gone away for a little while and when she comes back I've sort of resolved to really tell her how much I care for her.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: That's terrific.  Don't be afraid to be demonstrative.  You're sounding a lot more confident than when we last spoke.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: I am.  I'm really feeling pretty good.  I have a much stronger sense of how far I've come.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: As long as you keep remembering why.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Well, we talked about the whole disapproval thing.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: The whole disapproval thing.  If you allow yourself to get into a situation where someone else's potential disapproval becomes the focal point of your life -- then you're back to a life of fear, aren't you?  -- You're a prisoner to that again, and that isn't much of a life.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: I understand that.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: And please, don't for God's sake misinterpret that as being the voice of discouragement in any way --

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: No, no, no, no.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: On the contrary -- this is tremendous.  I mean, we're all frightened to death of disapproval and we're constantly hiding behind these layers we manufacture for ourselves -- and I'm not saying we should, you know, <u>declare</u> ourselves unhesitatingly to our fellow human beings in the interests of total openness and honesty --

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: That would be stupid.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: That would be monumentally stupid. All I'm saying is --

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: -- a sense of proportion.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: A sense of proportion.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Things are beginning to come to a head.  I can feel it.  And I want everything to be perfect.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: Who doesn't?

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: I've cultivated her interests so that now we have even more in common than ever.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: Well, now, don't go creating some artificial environment for yourself.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Oh no -- I mean, she's genuinely made me more fulfilled in many ways -- and I hope eventually to be able to teach her a few things, too.  What I mean is, I guess I'm still waiting for just that right -- synthesis between us -- where everything will be understood between us without even the need for words.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: It's not going to happen unless you make it happen, my friend. You're going to have to assert yourself a little bit more.  <u>Show</u> your affection.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Yeah, maybe you're right. Everything else is just an excuse. I'm treating the situation with kid gloves because I'm afraid of losing her.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: <u>Ask</u> her how she feels.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: I should.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: You have to put yourself out there a bit more.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: Because life isn't about playing it safe.  Life is about taking risks.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: Well, these are good signs -- she's broken up with him and the two of you seem to be developing quite a rapport.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: I <u>know</u>.  I just feel that the relationship has reached that delicate stage where the slightest little thing could wreck the careful groundwork I've laid up till now.

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: I can't help you if you don't help yourself.  It's really up to you. Brooding endlessly isn't going to help matters any.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: There's so much I want to say to her, it's all jumbled up in my mind, and I don't want her to misunderstand --

turns.speaker: THERAPIST
turns.text: Well, you'll just have to <u>make</u> her understand.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Oh, well, do you fix refrigerators?

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Well, can I make an appointment?

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Maybe I could take a look at it now.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Oh, great.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Yeah, that was easy.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Do you do washing machines, too?

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Just show me the way.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Everything breaks at once.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Isn't that always the way?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: So, you're just kind of a roving --

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: -- General handyman, yeah.  I do carpentry, too, painting, almost any odd job around the house.  I do housesitting while the owners are away.  In fact, that's why I've been in the area.  I've been living very close by.  Here's the part that's giving you trouble, but I won't be able to get a replacement till the stores open tomorrow morning.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Oh, that's fine.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I apologize for that scene with my husband.  You must have overheard.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: An occupational hazard, I'm afraid.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I bet.  Going into people's homes.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: It's a living.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Do you have a family?

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Uh, no -- I've never really found the time to settle down.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: You must value your independence.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Yeah, I've always been able to make my way in the world.  I don't like having to rely on other people.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: It's nice that you can make that choice.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: I was alone a lot as a child.  No one to compete with.  My parents ensured that I found happiness in the smallest things.  When you're all alone it's your own world, you don't have to take orders from anybody.  You don't necessarily believe the stories people tell you.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Not me, I fell for it right down the line.  Be a good girl and believe all the fairy tales.  He married me because I was pretty.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Because you <u>were</u> pretty?

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: I was driving by -- I saw all the cars.  Are you all right?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Yeah, I'm okay -- it's been a long night.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Can I tell you tomorrow?  I think I...

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: I was thinking about our conversation the other day -- what you said about choices.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Uh huh.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: Yeah, you know, that in life you really have to choose what you want to do.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Listen, I'm sorry, but it's really late -- you don't have to come tomorrow to work on the floor.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: It is tomorrow.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Yeah, right -- I really have to go to bed.

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: I think we should talk first.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: About what?

turns.speaker: HIDER
turns.text: About us.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Mr. Sykes, I think you should go home.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: I found a cent!

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: "Find a penny, pick it up, all day long you'll have good luck!"

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: '"... or I'll huff and I'll puff and I'll blow your house down!" And inside their new house, the three little pigs just laughed -- '

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: 'Who's afraid of the Big Bad Wolf, the Big Bad Wolf...'

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Hey.  Have a nice time -- it's a good school.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Bye, Neil!

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Baby, what is it?

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: I'm thirsty.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Aw, okay.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: It's the middle of the night, sweetie.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: A man scared me.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: A man?  Was it a dream?

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Uh huh.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Your daddy and I are kind of mad at each other right now, so we have to spend some time apart.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Why are you mad at each other?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: You know how sometimes Neil bugs you and you just get up and walk away from him?

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Uh huh.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Well, that's what happens with grownups, too.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Did Daddy tease you?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Yes, he did, and I don't like it any more than you do.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Daddy's gone where Rudolf went and isn't coming back!

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Holly -- that's not so.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: "Hi. I'm Mr. Edgar!"  Look, Mommy, it doesn't even hurt him.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Well, what do you want me to do, Rita -- I can't just forget fifteen years of marriage.  Well, of course I know <u>you</u> can.  No, Rita, I -- what was that?  -- oh, I thought I heard something on the line.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Mommy!

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: It's okay, baby, the police are coming.

turns.speaker: RITA
turns.text: You've done a really great job with the house.  It's great!

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Yeah.  There's still a lot I want to do.  It's not quite... the kids aren't really settled in yet. Even the dog has been terribly high-strung and whines a lot since we've been here.  Look, he hasn't even come in for his food today.

turns.speaker: RITA
turns.text: So you don't have anything concrete?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: No, I told you.  A whiff of perfume on his shirt.

turns.speaker: RITA
turns.text: Have you just plain asked him?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I've asked him what's wrong.

turns.speaker: RITA
turns.text: And?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: The same thing -- his business pressures, the whole move and everything.  He's frantic about nailing this new job, worried about screwing over his present boss.

turns.speaker: RITA
turns.text: I'm sure that's all it is, honey. Maybe you both just need a vacation.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I've tried to get him to agree to one.  I just -- I don't know... I'm getting such weird vibes lately.

turns.speaker: RITA
turns.text: Don't drive yourself crazy.  It's probably nothing.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Rita, he's only twelve years old,

turns.speaker: RITA
turns.text: He'll never appreciate it more.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: C'mon, kids, let's go.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: "We don't want to be late for our first day of school."

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Why can't you just drive me to my old school every morning?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Because you'd have to get up at five a.m., would you like that?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: I could take a cab on the way home.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Here, take this out to the table.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: But there's this <u>psycho</u>.  Really. Mom, there's a psycho I have to deal with <u>every day</u>.  I don't know why they let a psycho even go to school!

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Has anyone seen Rudolf?  I don't think he came in last night.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: No, honey, I haven't seen him. Didn't you feed him this morning?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: RUDOLF!

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: He doesn't have a temperature.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: I can't help it if my homework is torn to shreds three times a week by someone <u>much</u> bigger than me</u>.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Thank God.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I think we got it just in time before the ink dried.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Whew.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: The pocket's a cinch -- I'll sew it up for you after dinner, okay?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Thanks, Mom.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Neil, you could have burned the house down!

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: I don't <u>know</u> how it started!

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Where'd he go?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: He's staying with a friend.  Hurry up now, you'll be late for school.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Neil -- what --

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Mom, <u>there's somebody in the</u> <u>house</u>!

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Honey --

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Mom, I heard someone downstairs!

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Honey, do you want some hot chocolate?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: No, thanks, Mom -- I'll go up to bed now.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Do you want me to come up and tuck you in?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: That's okay, Mom.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Neil, calm down.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Neil, don't leave the back doors open -- I don't want Holly near the pool.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: We'd have to get one of those sliding covers for the pool.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I hear what you're saying, but I know what you're thinking.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: You're thinking exactly what I thought when I first saw this house,

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: This -- is -- the -- one -- for -- us.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Stop knowing me so well.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I know it's at the high end of our range --

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: High end?  Honey, it's a whole new budget.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: But it's what we want.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: You wanted furniture too, didn't you?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: They don't expect to get what they're asking.  Let's make an offer.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: You want me to bargain at the high end of our range?  -- I'll have a stroke.  I've got to save all my sweat for my meeting in three weeks.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: You could have a pool to cool off in.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: It's a nice pool, isn't it?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: And it's a shorter commute.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: It'll be even shorter if I get that new job.  Come on.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: What if someone else buys it in the meantime?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Honey, nobody buys a house overnight -- if someone else comes back at them, well, we might have to make a counter offer.  But we can't look too eager or we'll get screwed.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: We're going to think about it.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: It's very nice, but it's still a little pricey for us.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: How were we -- were we cool?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Paul Newman in "The Hustler."

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Good -- that's what I was trying to project.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: <u>Now</u>, Neil.  Stop teasing your sister.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Damn.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Did you hear that?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Did you hear what he said?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: He made, you know, a remark.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Honey, are you okay?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: -- And keep my kids away from his property -- who the hell does he think he is?  Some nice neighborhood.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Honey, the meeting today is going to be fine.  Don't get in an uproar.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: I know.  It's just having to pass muster with these juniors before the senior partner even agrees to see me.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: It's just a dumb game they play. You want to be at a bigger firm, get used to the politics.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: How was lunch?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: How was your lunch with Charlie?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Oh -- great.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Well, did he hear anything about your prospects for the new job?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: <u>No</u>.  If I hear anything you'll be the first to know, all right?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Do you remember who gave us this?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: There's no card or anything.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I hear things in this house,

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: All new houses have noises.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: How long does it have to be a new house?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: One day before we know it it'll be an old house and we'll be old in it -- and I'll still be paying for it.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Neil's still having a bad time at school.  I feel terrible seeing him so upset all the time.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: He's made some friends, hasn't he?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: I mean, he's a smart kid, he'll get by -- he takes after me. You're too sensitive.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I know someone else who's sensitive.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Yeah, I guess it would be good for us to get away for a while.  Maybe Rudolf got the same idea.  Dogs need a change of scene, too, from time to time.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Someone nice will find him if he gets lost.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: No, I'm not kidding you, <u>Philip</u>.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: What next?!  -- A strange bra under my pillow!

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I <u>remember</u> what day you wore that jacket.  It was <u>Monday</u>.  The day you were all day in <u>meetings</u> again?  And had to send out for <u>sandwiches</u>?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Honey, you know what I've been like lately... I've been a total zombie.  I have no idea what that was doing in my pocket.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Well, what about <u>these</u>?  Do you usually put your <u>carbons</u> in your pocket, too?!

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Sweetheart, this is a very risky time for me right now.  Maybe you don't appreciate that.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I don't care, Philip.  You want to go chasing Barbara Zelman, go ahead.  Just watch out for those buck teeth.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Barbara <u>Zelman</u>?  I don't believe this!

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Do you usually pay for Charlie? At "Trattoria <u>Valentino</u>"?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Honey, I can't track of all the meals Charlie and I have been having.  This is a delicate time. If it leaks out that I'm jumping ship before I'm set up someplace else I could be out on my ear before I'm ready with nothing. With <u>nothing</u>.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: There <u>are</u> people who do things because they <u>want</u> to get caught.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Who told you that -- someone on the radio?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Fuck you, Philip.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I thought we'd be happy here.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Honey, I'm sorry, I think the vacation will be a good break for both of us.  You'll see.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: The cab's waiting!

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Where should I hide the car keys?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: I don't know -- put 'em in the drawer with all the Chinese take- away menus.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Did you lock the garage door?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Did the cleaning woman come?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Yeah -- she did a good job.  This glass looks brand-new.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: The floor has a nice shine to it.  Oh God -- we have twenty-two messages on the machine.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Did she water this plant?  It looks a little bent out of shape.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: He wants to see me!

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Philip!  The senior partner?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: His secretary just confirmed.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Oh baby.
